item.title: Pavement tile dangerously elevated, 27th January
item.description:
This has been reported as a broken bollard, but it’s the pavement tile which is dangerously elevated around the bollard, which appears to be intact. This is a major trip hazard especially at night. This is on Lafone street, near the corner of Shad Thames, across from the side of Pizza Express

Nearest road to the pin placed on the map (automatically generated by OpenStreetMap): 37, Shad Thames, Bermondsey, Greater London
Report on FixMyStreet

item.title: Abandoned car seat, 27th January
item.description:

Nearest road to the pin placed on the map (automatically generated by OpenStreetMap): Prince's Plain, Bromley Common, Greater London

item.title: Dog waste bin is rarely emptied, 27th January
item.description:
The bin for dog waste is not being emptied and full bags are left by the side of the bin. Dog mess on the local streets is increasing, not helped by this overflowing dog waste bin. Perhaps some signs again in the local area about cleaning up after your dog would help. Thank you.

Nearest road to the pin placed on the map (automatically generated by OpenStreetMap): Aylesbury Road, Walworth, Greater London
Report on FixMyStreet

item.title: Recurrent fly‑tipping by identified neighbour at Stevenson Crescent, 27th January
item.description:
Ongoing recurrent fly‑tipping is taking place in the communal/bin area at SE16 3EN. For almost four years, bulk household waste (bags of rubbish, furniture, packaging) has been regularly dumped there by identifiable Hyde Housing social tenants, using another building’s waste area instead of their own household bins and contrary to tenancy and local waste rules. Multiple incidents have been logged with dates, times and photographs, and in many cases items can be clearly linked to specific flats (for example, address labels and repeat patterns of disposal). A detailed incident log and all evidence can be provided on request. The landlord has been notified many times but the dumping continues and bulk‑waste clearances are recharged through service charges, so costs caused by identifiable offenders are being passed on to other residents. Environmental enforcement is requested to treat this as recurrent fly‑tipping by identifiable residents at known addresses, review the incident log and evidence, take firm enforcement action under fly‑tipping legislation (including suitable Fixed Penalty Notices and, where justified, prosecution), and ensure future clean‑up costs are recovered from those responsible rather than compliant residents.

Nearest road to the pin placed on the map (automatically generated by OpenStreetMap): Stevenson Crescent, Bermondsey, Greater London
Report on FixMyStreet
